{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3327386,"name":"Ethan Jiang","username":"WawerMelon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wawermelon/{size}/217790_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T00:20:35.797Z","cooked":"

Currently, I am attempting to make a code to run a set of NEO motors for a set time. They successfully start running, but never stop after the given real amount of time. The code is meantto spin the motors for a total of 3 seconds, the two shooter motors for the entire duration and the intake (named “DJMotor”) motor for the last 1.5 seconds. Through testing, I noticed the timer would be really slow compared to when the method is not running. I’m not sure how to fix that. Any ideas?
Jukebox.java (3.3 KB)
This is our intake/shooter subsystem ^^^
For us its 1 day till comp lol, ty in advance for saving our team

Note: We are using a timer in the first place because the NEOs don’t have encoders. The code is going to be used in autonomous mode.

WawerMelon:

because the NEOs don’t have encoders

NEOs do have encoders though.

Domtech:

NEOs do have encoders though.

I thought they don’t have encoders unless the hall-effect encoder that comes with the NEO is attached. Our robot does not have that attached on the NEOs, meaning it can’t use the encoders. Am I wrong?

Are we talking about the same motor?

This is NEO, it has a built in hall-effect encoder:

image1112×810 29.8 KB

This is a NEO 550, it also has a built in hall-effect encoder:

image1182×865 30.4 KB

This is a NEO Vortex, it also has a built in encoder (IDK exactly what kind):

image1250×1225 45.4 KB

These are all sensored brushless motors meaning the controller needs the encoder to know which phase to send power to. None of them come with an external encoder.

Rev does make a through-bore encoder that can be used with the SparkMAX with a brushed motor, or in addition to the brushless motor hall-effect encoder using either the alternate encoder adapter board or the absolute adapter board depending on which mode you want.

image986×968 39.4 KB

Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327471,"name":"boof19","username":"boof19","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/boof19/{size}/150466_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T02:05:51.916Z","cooked":"

The brake function doesn’t actually tell the motor to stop so it will still run the last motor power you sent. If you want the motor to stop just send set(0) at the end.

The setIdleMode only tells the motor how it should reach the no power state:
IdleMode.kBrake - send power back to the motor in the reverse direction, slowing it down fast and adding some resistance.
IdleMode.kCoast - don’t send power to the motor, let it coast down slowly to zero with the resistance in the system.
